Authors:
Carlos Alberto Salvador Montoya, Samuel Galvão Elias,
Orlando F. Popoff, Gerardo Lucio Robledo, Carlos Urcelay, Aristóteles
Góes-Neto, Sebastían Martínez, Elisandro Ricardo Drechsler-Santos
Title:
Neotropical studies on Hymenochaetaceae: unveiling a
diversity and endemicity in Phellinotus
Keywords:
xanthocroic polypores, endemic fungi, phylogenetic
lineages, SDTF species, taxonomy
Abstract:
Phellinotus, a neotropical genus of wood-decay fungi,
common on living members of the family Fabaceae, was initially described
including only two species, P. neoaridus and P. piptadeniae.
Morphological revisions, phylogenetic relationships, and host
distribution, of differents specimens resemblimg P. neoaridus and P.
piptadeniae revealed three new species in the genus, named here as P.
magnoporatus, P. teixeirae and P. xerophiticus. Furthermore, P.
piptadeniae has a narrower concept in its morphology and distribution,
and both P. neoaridus and P. teixeirae present a distribution range
restricted to seasonally dry tropical forests in South America.
Additionally, based on detailed morphological revisions, Phellinus
badius, Phellinus resinaceus and Phellinus scaber are transferred to
Phellinotus. The geographic distribution and host range of the genus are
discussed.
